clean_story:
"Sun as compass. Shadows as clocks.

Desert navigation tricks are simple methods to find direction without tools.

Most people think you need a GPS or map to cross a desert.
But ancient travelers used the sun, stars, and even animal tracks to guide them.

Here’s how it works:
Place a stick in the sand—its shadow points west in the morning, east in the afternoon.
At noon, the shortest shadow points north.
This is the "shadow-stick method. "

At night, the North Star (Polaris) stays fixed while others move.
Follow it north.
In the southern hemisphere, use the Southern Cross constellation instead.

Even cacti and dunes help:
In the Sahara, dunes often form in long lines parallel to prevailing winds—useful for keeping a straight path.
Some cacti grow more on their south side, where sunlight is strongest.

Bedouins read tiny details—footprints, wind patterns, even how sand shifts after a storm.
A single misstep can mean miles off course.

Three related subjects are star-based sailing routes, animal migration paths, and sandstorm survival tactics. "
